summaryText: Pastor Travis Hearn delivers a powerful sermon on the fight for peace in our relationships, diving deep into the spiritual warfare that often undermines our harmony. Using musical metaphors and keyboard demonstrations, PT illustrates how relationships should sound like beautiful, harmonious chords, but often end up as discordant, chaotic noise. The key message? Don't fight the person, fight the problem. Our real enemy isn't each other, but the spiritual forces working to divide us. Pastor Travis challenges us to be peacemakers, not just peaceful people, highlighting that true peace requires active effort, especially when tensions are high. He reveals that our greatest battles happen in our minds, and we must guard our hearts and mouths carefully. The sermon is a compelling call to rise above conflict, choose righteousness over being right, and allow God's spirit to transform our relationships from the inside out.
mainPoints: Don't fight the person, fight the problem
Our greatest battle is in our mind
Be a peacemaker, not just peaceful

versesMentioned.text: Live in harmony with one another.

Love is patient, love is kind. It does not envy, it does not boast, it is not proud. It does not dishonor others, it is not self-seeking, it is not easily angered, it keeps no record of wrongs. Love does not delight in evil but rejoices with the truth. It always protects, always trusts, always hopes, always perseveres. Love never fails.

What causes fights and quarrels among you? Don't they come from your desires that battle within you? You desire but do not have, so you kill. You covet but you cannot get what you want, so you quarrel and fight.
If a house is divided against itself, that house cannot stand.

For our struggle is not against flesh and blood, but against the rulers, against the authorities, against the powers of this dark world and against the spiritual forces of evil in the heavenly realms.
If it is possible, as far as it depends on you, live at peace with everyone.
Blessed are the peacemakers, for they will be called children of God.
Above all else, guard your heart, for everything you do flows from it.
In addition to all this, take up the shield of faith, with which you can extinguish all the flaming arrows of the evil one.
The mind governed by the flesh is death, but the mind governed by the Spirit is life and peace.

Do not be anxious about anything, but in every situation, by prayer and petition, with thanksgiving, present your requests to God. And the peace of God, which transcends all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.
Set a guard over my mouth, Lord; keep watch over the door of my lips.

Likewise, the tongue is a small part of the body, but it makes great boasts. Consider what a great forest is set on fire by a small spark. The tongue also is a fire, a world of evil among the parts of the body. It corrupts the whole body, sets the whole course of one's life on fire, and is itself set on fire by hell. All kinds of animals, birds, reptiles and sea creatures are being tamed and have been tamed by mankind, but no human being can tame the tongue. It is a restless evil, full of deadly poison. With the tongue we praise our Lord and Father, and with it we curse human beings, who have been made in God's likeness. Out of the same mouth come praise and cursing. My brothers and sisters, this should not be.
My dear brothers and sisters, take note of this: Everyone should be quick to listen, slow to speak and slow to become angry.
A gentle answer turns away wrath, but a harsh word stirs up anger.
A good man brings good things out of the good stored up in his heart, and an evil man brings evil things out of the evil stored up in his heart. For the mouth speaks what the heart is full of.
But now you must also rid yourselves of all such things as these: anger, rage, malice, slander, and filthy language from your lips.
Do not let any unwholesome talk come out of your mouths, but only what is helpful for building others up according to their needs, that it may benefit those who listen.
I have told you these things, so that in me you may have peace. In this world you will have trouble. But take heart! I have overcome the world.

Monday.scripture: Proverbs 15:1: 'A gentle answer turns away wrath, but a harsh word stirs up anger.'
Monday.action: In every conversation today, pause before responding. Ask yourself: 'Am I responding with gentleness or am I trying to prove a point?'
Monday.prayer: Lord, help me to be slow to anger and quick to listen. Give me a gentle spirit that reflects Your love in my interactions today. Amen.

Tuesday.scripture: Ephesians 4:29: 'Do not let any unwholesome talk come out of your mouths, but only what is helpful for building others up according to their needs, that it may benefit those who listen.'
Tuesday.focus: Building up instead of tearing down
Tuesday.action: Make it your mission to genuinely compliment or encourage at least three people today. Be specific and sincere.
Tuesday.prayer: God, transform my words into instruments of healing and encouragement. Help me see others through Your eyes and speak life into their situations. Amen.

Wednesday.scripture: Proverbs 4:23: 'Above all else, guard your heart, for everything you do flows from it.'
Wednesday.focus: Protecting your inner emotional and spiritual environment
Wednesday.action: Do a 'media detox' today. Limit social media, news, and negative content. Instead, fill your mind with worship music, scripture, or inspirational content.
Wednesday.prayer: Holy Spirit, be the guardian of my heart and mind. Help me filter what I allow to enter my thoughts and influence my emotions. Amen.

Thursday.scripture: James 1:19: 'My dear brothers and sisters, take note of this: Everyone should be quick to listen, slow to speak and slow to become angry.'
Thursday.action: In your next conversation, practice listening without immediately preparing your response. Ask clarifying questions and truly seek to understand the other person's perspective.
Thursday.prayer: Lord, give me patience and humility to truly listen. Help me value understanding over being understood. Teach me to listen with compassion. Amen.

Friday.scripture: Romans 12:18: 'If it is possible, as far as it depends on you, live at peace with everyone.'
Friday.action: Reach out to someone with whom you have unresolved tension. Initiate a conversation of reconciliation or healing, even if it's just a small step.
Friday.prayer: Father, give me courage to be a bridge-builder. Help me to extend grace and seek peace, even when it's uncomfortable. Show me practical ways to demonstrate Your love. Amen.

Saturday.scripture: Philippians 4:6-7: 'Do not be anxious about anything, but in every situation, by prayer and petition, with thanksgiving, present your requests to God. And the peace of God, which transcends all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus.'
Saturday.action: Spend extended time in prayer today. Write down your anxieties and deliberately surrender them to God. Practice thanksgiving even in challenging circumstances.
Saturday.prayer: Heavenly Father, I surrender my worries and fears to You. Fill me with Your supernatural peace that goes beyond human understanding. Help me trust You completely. Amen.
